Merge pull request #318 from jasom/bug/gracefull-shutdown

Bug/gracefull shutdown

Fix bug in SuperPoll when socket errors happen (#317)

There was an underlying assumption that the return value of zmq_poll
would be equal to the number of items with revents set.  This is not
actually true, as polling for read/write without error can return when
the sockets are in an error state, with no bits set in revents.

This causes it to read past the end of the valid entries in the data
array.

It is suspected to be a cause of the crash in #316

Fix for uninitialized memory after array expansion (#321)

Valgrind complains about "Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)" because memset isn't properly initializing the newly expanded chunk of the darray. I tested this by throwing 1000000 values in a darray then clearing it, and noticed Valgrind didn't like line 67 in darray_clear().

```
if(array->contents[i] != NULL) {
```

Because it's potentially uninitialized

Fix many bugs in signal handler

The MURDER value was overwritten and then ignored in an else statement

The socket was closed, which didn't always trigger a return from
zmq_poll (even worse, the FD could theoretically get reused on a busy
server).  Switching to shutdown() guarantees operations will trigger an
error on that FD.

Per Justin's request, we don't return an error code on a single SIGTERM.
If you want it to die immediately with an error, either send two
SIGTERMs or just use SIGKILL (this is what SIGKILL is for anyways).

Make build-directories order-only (#319)

Directories change their modification time, so can't directly depend on
them.  Instead there is a rule to ensure that they exist.  What was
missing is that the dependency should not force a rebuild of everything
that depends on it.

Use strncpy instead of memcpy (#320)

This was found with ASAN

Original makefile is still available with make -f localmbedtls.mak

It appears to serve the same purpose and LDFLAGS is more standard.

Merge pull request #312 from fanout/fix-download-credits

send initial download credits only once per connection

Since request IDs made over the same connection are reused, download credits are really connection-based rather than request-based. Initial credits should be provided only at the time of the first request. All credits after that are given whenever writes to connections succeed.

Re-giving credits for each new request actually causes an overgiving of credits, since the handler will have already gotten credits for all of its earlier writes. The handler then ends up with more credits than MAX_CREDITS, which may cause the handler to write too much in the next response, causing the connection to be dropped (Mongrel2 kills the connection if pending bytes exceeds MAX_CREDITS).
enable tcp keep alive
send initial download credits only once per connection
fix small memory leak with websocket communication

Merge PR #296 into develop
Update mbedtls config patch
Reinstate legacy ciphersuite aliases for DHE-RSA

Lookup ciphersuites in mbedtls directly

This removes the "whitelist" of configurable ciphersuites in server.c and
replaces it with a call to search the polarssl table of ciphersuites. The table
was never sufficient for blocking weak ciphers since the default set of ciphers
always bypassed it.

Since polarssl requires ciphersuite names to use dashes, any underscores (used
previously) in teh ciphersuite name are replaced by dashes and both are
supported in the config file.

PolarSSL is asked to verify that a ciphersuite is supported through either
ssl_ciphersuite_from_id or ssl_ciphersuite_from_string instead of using ifdefs.
Use 2048-bit DH parameters from RFC5114 by default
Re-enable Diffie-Hellman in mbedtls

Pull request #181

In handler mode, set special header REMOTE_ADDR containing the IP
address of the requesting client. Setting no_clobber_xff prevents
X-FORWARDED-FOR from being touched in handler mode.

Proxy mode remains unchanged. REMOTE_ADDR is not set in that context,
and X-FORWARDED-FOR is always set/replaced (no_clobber_xff has no
effect on proxy mode).

Merge pull request #132 from moai/develop

Call filters that register for the CLOSE event(cherry picked from commit 73eb1b3f33306d1a48fded9081d41c7437153fbf)

Change websockets to pass opening handshake on

This allows the client to negotiate extensions.  We don't fully support
extensions yet, since mongrel2 always defragments packets, which is
disallowed in the presence of unknown extensions.  On the other hand,
defragmenting packets in e.g. python is incredibly slow vs. C so I think
it's a resonable middle ground right now.

Note that if someone sends an opening handshake, followed by a websocket
frame, we will start processing those frames regardless of whether or
not the handler signals it supports websockets by replying with a
response.  This *may* be a security vulnerability, I haven't determined
that yet.
(cherry picked from commit 4c761ee1df5e8a9251d982392d30f795a916ef5e)

IOBuf_read doesn't return an error when fd is closed

So we need to detect this in read_all

Hack to work around inifinite loop

When the hotlist is full, this code will loop forever trying to add the
socket to the hotlist.  A 100ms sleep will let things make progress; the
better long-term solution is to forcibly evict a FD from the hotlist to
make room since handler sockets should always have priority, but that's
a more complicated change

Change websockets to pass opening handshake on

This allows the client to negotiate extensions.  We don't fully support
extensions yet, since mongrel2 always defragments packets, which is
disallowed in the presence of unknown extensions.  On the other hand,
defragmenting packets in e.g. python is incredibly slow vs. C so I think
it's a resonable middle ground right now.

Note that if someone sends an opening handshake, followed by a websocket
frame, we will start processing those frames regardless of whether or
not the handler signals it supports websockets by replying with a
response.  This *may* be a security vulnerability, I haven't determined
that yet.

Merge branch 'feature/anyzmq' into develop

Implement compatibility with 0MQ 2.1.X and 3.1.X APIs and convert to
use the 0MQ 3.1.1 API for zmq_msg_send, zmq_msg_recv and zmq_poll.

Instead of #include <zmq.h>, we now #include "zmq_compat.h", which
implements the 0MQ 3.1.1 API in terms of the 0MQ 3.1.0 or 2.1.X APIs
(whichever is provided at compile time). Preserves the return value
assumptions of mqsend/mqrecv as originally implemented on the 0MQ 2.1.X
API, when compiled with 0MQ 3.1.X. All unit tests pass, when compiled
with 0MQ 2.1.11, 3.1.0 and 3.1.1.

Merge pull request #113 from dermoth/develop

Develop - documentation fixes

Add a note about possible need for proc/ in chroot

On some systems (apparently those using the system PGM library instead
of the one bundled with ZeroMQ) mongrel2 will crash during zmq_init if
/proc isn't accessible. Symptoms are being able to run mongrel2 as a
normal used, but as soon as root is used and mongrel2 does a chroot, it
will print the following warning and crash:

  Warn: Linux kernel reports no Time Stamp Counter (TSC).

This issue has been reported in:
  https://github.com/zedshaw/mongrel2/issues/78
Add mention of the disable.access_logging setting

Change websocket python API

Make it more like the http&jssocket API

Merge pull request #111 from typingArtist/develop

3 fixes for fixing races, reducing error log utilization and allowing more than 65535 connections

Fix racey socket close to just a shutdown socket operation. This
avoids file descriptor (fd) reuse of the OS while the other task
is still expecting to be allowed to communicate with the socket
under the old fd.
Fix for superfluous close calls leading to nothing more than alot of log file entries.
Fix wrong ident (id) boundary check. ids can span the whole range of the type.
Fix radixmap blindly assuming that keys cannot alias after a wraparound

Merge pull request #108 from ralphbean/develop

Ignoring tools/procer/procer

Ignoring tools/procer/procer

  It's a product of the build process and as such shouldn't be included
  in git.

Unregister the fd, even when there is an SSL error

Previously we skipped unregistering in the event of an SSL error, but we
still freed the IOBuf.  This lead to heap corruption.
Remove some debug cruft

Set FD of IOBuf to -1 on close

This should prevent us from using the IOBuf to do anything useful after a
close.  I also added a convenience function for registering a disconnect with
an IOBuf.

Also, change the handling of an empty handler message to be in the sending
task, so that we don't close the FD until all data has been flushed

Revert "Set FD of IOBuf to -1 on close"

This reverts commit 249b43f1ebd1fee5e8e9d2955840f3f22174c24f.
I meant to do this on develop.

Set FD of IOBuf to -1 on close

This should prevent us from using the IOBuf to do anything useful after
a close.  I also added a convenience function for registering a
disconnect with an IOBuf.

Also, change the handling of an empty handler message to be in the
sending task, so that we don't close the FD until all data has been
flushed

Cleanups and last minute bug fixes for the 1.7 release.
Some format strings were wrong for the off_t type.

Added back bigfiles support by changing *_stream_file callbacks to use off_t.

Ensured that this would work on 32-bit machines by #define'ing _FILE_OFFSET_BITS to be 64 (basically just makes off_t a 64-bit type).
Temporarily remove the >2G file support as it doesn't work quite right, then start working on another try.

Working initial first cut of config-anything feature.
Audit of the latest changes to the configuration loading.
Implemented a Server.use_ssl and refactored code to not use strtok and evil friends.
Added gitflow to the setup script
Make m2sh work with control port and tables again.

Instead of returning a http chunked response, just write 1GB chunks to
the IOBuf

The HTTP chunked response is meant to be used when we do not know the
size of the response, which in this case (serving a static file) is
not true.
Slight refactor of the giant file send code.
